Wierd. I haven't gotten any messages from this list, but when I log 
on to the website, I see people have responded. Thanks to everyone 
who have responded so far.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Dave Astels" <dave@s...> wrote:
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Bryce Fischer" <bryce@b...> wrote:
> <snip>
> 
> > Given that I have two methods of my class I need to test, 
SaveLicense 
> > and LoadLicense, should I write this as two separate tests or as 
a 
> > single test that incorporates both? To clarify, to load a 
license, I 
> > would need to have a saved license. The load license would then 
verify
> > that the information that was saved was loaded correctly.
> 
> The problem is saving, then loading, then verifying that the loaded
> object is equal to what was saved (if I understand your reasoning
> correctly) just tests that they you can load what you saved.  It
> doesn't verify that the format is correct.  Also, the two ate tied
> together.

You are understanding me correctly. Except that I'm able to do this:

1. Instantiate an object.
2. Initialize the object with known values.
3. Serialize the object.
4. Load object into another variable.
5. assertEquals on 2 objects.

I have implemented equals methods on my classes so if they are not 
equal (not the same, but equal). In fact, I do some tests on my 
equals functions by taking 2 objects that should be equal, and also 
comparing 2 objects that are not. I also verify that they are not the 
same objects (i.e. obj1 == obj2)

> I advise a separate test for each ("advise" because you don't work 
for
> me.. if you did, I'd "insist").  

And that's why I'm here. Trying to learn. In fact, I just got hired 
by this company and they don't do ANY testing... I'm trying to move 
them forward in this, so I appreciate the tips.

> And don't use real files if you can
> help it.  Use a mocked file for each test.  Save to a mock that 
knows
> what *should* be saved, then verify that that is what was saved.  
Read
> from a fake that will supply a serialized object in the correct
> format, then verify that the loaded object is correct.  If you're
> using Java you can work work with streams and not worry about files 
at
> all.  If the output format is textual (i.e. not binary) you can 
simply
> supply string streams in the test... Mocks can result in cleaner 
test
> code, though.

I'll look into Mocks. I've read a little about them, but I'm trying 
to take baby steps...

My main concern is that the functionality involved serializing to a 
file, so I thought I'd need to exercise that in a test (i.e., saving 
to a known location, then making sure it loads from the same known 
location, etc).

The output is binary, and I'm working with streams all the way until 
I actually write the file.

Thanks again for your tips, and I hope that my emails start arriving 
soon....
